DOC.HEAD: Parent of Wall Street Brokerage Reaches Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: L.F. Rothschild & Co., the Wall Street firm devastated by the 1987 stock market crash, is reforming as a smaller brokerage as its parent company seeks to restructure more than $100 million in debt in bankruptcy court. Creditors of the 90-year-old firm's parent company, L.F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., approved a plan to issue new bonds to replace those defaulted on last June, when the company sought bankruptcy court protection. ``We've gone about trying to intelligently refocus the broker-dealer, which was never part of the bankruptcy,'' Rothschild Chief Executive Joel E. Miller said in an interview Thursday. ``We're small and lean and well-capitalized for what we do.'' Since its parent sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law in June, Rothschild & Co. has shuffled its management and scaled down its businesses in an effort to stay alive. Founded in 1899, the brokerage has 45 workers, up from a low of about 35 earlier this year but a shadow of its peak employment of 2,200 before the Oct. 19, 1987, stock market crash. After suffering substantial losses in the crash, Rothschild systematically sold or abandoned its retail brokerage, public finance and municipal bond sales and trading operations. It also ceased over-the-counter market making, arbitrage and the selling and trading of government, mortgage-backed and high-grade corporate securities. Miller said the restructured brokerage would re-enter the retail brokerage and investment banking businesses. In November, the firm entered municipal securities trading and the capital markets business. Miller said the brokerage is contacting old clients and would increase advertising in January to twice a week in The Wall Street Journal and Investors Daily in an effort to find new customers. Rothschild Holdings in early 1988 became a subsidiary of Franklin Financial Services, which itself is a subsidiary of Ottawa, Kan.-based Franklin Savings Association. On Thursday, Franklin Savings said it would sell Rothschild next year. The thrift has blamed the brokerage company for its recent losses. Franklin Chairman Ernest M. Fleischer said that a group of Rothschild employees, led by Miller, ``expressed an interest'' in buying the company and that the group ``are the most likely buyers.'' As of Jan. 1, 1987, Rothschild ranked as the 18th largest U.S. securities firm with capital of $289 million. By the end of the year, Rothschild posted a $129 million annual loss, $56 million of which resulted from arbitrage and over-the-counter trading positions held during the Black Monday crash. Miller said the firm now has a net worth of about $20 million. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, Rothschild Holdings showed losses of $3.81 million on revenue of just $235,000. That compared with losses of $5.59 million on revenue of $65.0 million a year ago. Rothschild Holdings issued a statement Thursday saying its committee of unsecured creditors had approved the restructuring proposal. The brokerage subsidiary was not included in the bankruptcy filing. Under the debt restructuring, Rothschild Holdings plans to swap existing debt for zero-coupon debt in an attempt to cut current interest payments. Zero-coupon bonds are sold at a discount and redeemed at maturity at face value, and do not provide periodic interest payments. Rothschild Holdings plans to issue zero-coupon notes worth $29.8 million to replace the defaulted bonds valued at $101 million, the company said. In its bankruptcy court filing, Rothschild Holdings said its major creditors were Citicorp Investment Bank (Switzerland) with a $48 million claim, Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. with a $24.9 million claim and Cede & Co. with a $39 million claim. L.F. Rothschild is not connected with the New York investment bank Rothschild Inc.
